article:
2022 South Korean Presidential Election

The 2022 South Korean presidential election was held on March 9, 2022, to elect the next President of South Korea. The election was won by Yoon Suk-yeol of the People Power Party, who defeated Lee Jae-myung of the Democratic Party in a closely contested race.

# Background

The 2022 presidential election was the 20th presidential election in South Korea since the country's transition to democracy in 1987. The election was held to choose a successor to incumbent President Moon Jae-in, who was term-limited and could not run for re-election. The election was seen as a crucial moment for South Korea, with the country facing challenges such as a slowing economy, rising inequality, and tensions with North Korea.

# Electoral System

The President of South Korea is elected using a single-member plurality voting system, where the candidate with the most votes wins the election. The election is held on a single day, and voters cast their ballots for one of the registered candidates. The president serves a five-year term, and is limited to a single term in office.

# Nominations

## Democratic Party

### Primary Campaign

The Democratic Party held a primary election to select its candidate for the presidential election. The primary campaign was dominated by Lee Jae-myung, the governor of Gyeonggi Province, and Lee Nak-yon, the former prime minister. The primary campaign was marked by infighting between the two candidates, with Lee Jae-myung ultimately emerging as the winner.

### Primary Schedule and Process

The primary election was held on October 10, 2021, and was open to all members of the Democratic Party. The primary was held using a combination of online and offline voting, with voters casting their ballots for one of the five candidates.

#### Primary Results

The results of the primary election were as follows:

* Lee Jae-myung: 50.29%
* Lee Nak-yon: 39.14%
* Choo Mi-ae: 6.44%
* Park Yong-jin: 2.44%
* Kim Du-kwan: 1.69%

### Candidate

Lee Jae-myung was born on October 22, 1964, in Andong, North Gyeongsang Province. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a prosecutor before entering politics. Lee was elected as the governor of Gyeonggi Province in 2018, and served as the leader of the Democratic Party from 2020 to 2021.

### Other Primary Candidates

* Lee Nak-yon: Lee Nak-yon was born on December 20, 1951, in Jongno-gu, Seoul. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a journalist before entering politics. Lee served as the prime minister from 2017 to 2020.
* Choo Mi-ae: Choo Mi-ae was born on October 23, 1958, in Gwangju. She graduated from Ewha Womans University and served as a lawyer before entering politics. Choo served as the justice minister from 2020 to 2021.
* Park Yong-jin: Park Yong-jin was born on June 6, 1971, in Busan. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a lawyer before entering politics.
* Kim Du-kwan: Kim Du-kwan was born on December 22, 1959, in Jeonju. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a lawyer before entering politics.

### Eliminated Candidates

* Kim Jin-pyo: Kim Jin-pyo was born on January 6, 1947, in Busan. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a lawyer before entering politics.
* Moon Hee-sang: Moon Hee-sang was born on March 13, 1947, in Busan. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a lawyer before entering politics.

### Withdrawn Candidates

* Chung Sye-kyun: Chung Sye-kyun was born on January 1, 1950, in Jinju. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a lawyer before entering politics. Chung served as the speaker of the National Assembly from 2020 to 2021.

## People Power Party

### Primary Campaign

The People Power Party held a primary election to select its candidate for the presidential election. The primary campaign was dominated by Yoon Suk-yeol, the former prosecutor general, and Hong Joon-pyo, the former governor of South Gyeongsang Province. The primary campaign was marked by infighting between the two candidates, with Yoon Suk-yeol ultimately emerging as the winner.

#### Primary Results

The results of the primary election were as follows:

* Yoon Suk-yeol: 48.83%
* Hong Joon-pyo: 41.50%
* Won Hee-ryong: 6.43%
* Lee Jun-seok: 3.24%

### Candidate

Yoon Suk-yeol was born on December 18, 1960, in Seoul. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a prosecutor before entering politics. Yoon served as the prosecutor general from 2019 to 2021.

### Other Candidates

* Hong Joon-pyo: Hong Joon-pyo was born on March 17, 1955, in Changnyeong County, South Gyeongsang Province. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a lawyer before entering politics. Hong served as the governor of South Gyeongsang Province from 2012 to 2017.
* Won Hee-ryong: Won Hee-ryong was born on June 18, 1964, in Seoul. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a lawyer before entering politics.

### Withdrawn Candidates

* Na Kyung-won: Na Kyung-won was born on December 6, 1963, in Seoul. She graduated from Seoul National University and served as a lawyer before entering politics.

### Did Not Run

* Lee Cheol-hee: Lee Cheol-hee was born on December 29, 1953, in Busan. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a lawyer before entering politics.

## Justice Party

### Candidate

Sim Sang-jung was born on February 20, 1959, in Seoul. She graduated from Ewha Womans University and served as a lawyer before entering politics. Sim served as the leader of the Justice Party from 2015 to 2020.

### Other Primary Candidates

* Lee Jung-mi: Lee Jung-mi was born on March 17, 1965, in Seoul. She graduated from Ewha Womans University and served as a lawyer before entering politics.

## People Party

### Candidate

Ahn Cheol-soo was born on February 26, 1962, in Busan. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a doctor before entering politics. Ahn served as the leader of the People Party from 2020 to 2021.

## Minor Party Candidates

* Oh Jun-ho: Oh Jun-ho was born on July 2, 1955, in Seoul. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a lawyer before entering politics.
* Kim Min-gi: Kim Min-gi was born on November 27, 1962, in Seoul. He graduated from Seoul National University and served as a lawyer before entering politics.

# Registered Candidates

The following candidates were registered for the presidential election:

* Lee Jae-myung (Democratic Party)
* Yoon Suk-yeol (People Power Party)
* Sim Sang-jung (Justice Party)
* Ahn Cheol-soo (People Party)
* Oh Jun-ho (Basic Income Party)
* Kim Min-gi (Minsaeng Party)
* Kim Jae-jeon (Transition Korea)
* Cho Won-jin (Our Republican Party)
* Lee Gyeong-hee (Unification Democratic Party)
* Ok Soo-ho (Minsaeng Party)

# Opinion Polling

Opinion polls were conducted regularly throughout the campaign period to gauge public opinion on the candidates. The polls showed a close contest between Lee Jae-myung and Yoon Suk-yeol, with Sim Sang-jung and Ahn Cheol-soo trailing behind.

# Campaign Developments

## Campaign Issues

The campaign focused on several key issues, including the economy, education, and foreign policy. The candidates proposed various policies to address these issues, including increasing the minimum wage, improving the education system, and strengthening diplomatic relations with other countries.

## Negative Campaigning and Candidate Unpopularity

The campaign was marked by negative campaigning, with the candidates and their parties attacking each other's policies and personal characters. The negative campaigning led to a decline in public trust in the candidates and the political parties.

## Recruitment of Left-Wing Feminists to the Conservative Camps

The campaign saw a significant recruitment of left-wing feminists to the conservative camps, including the People Power Party. The move was seen as an attempt to attract liberal voters and to challenge the dominance of the Democratic Party on social issues.

## Infighting in Yoon's Campaign Team and PPP

The campaign was marked by infighting within Yoon Suk-yeol's campaign team and the People Power Party. The infighting was centered on the party's leadership and the direction of the campaign.

## Sim Sang-jung Suspends Campaign Activities

Sim Sang-jung suspended her campaign activities for several days due to health reasons. The move raised concerns about her ability to continue with the campaign.

## Bus Accident Deaths Involving Ahn Cheol-soo's Campaigners

A bus carrying Ahn Cheol-soo's campaigners was involved in a fatal accident, resulting in the deaths of several people. The accident raised concerns about the safety of the campaign teams.

## Ahn's Withdrawal from the Campaign, Endorsing Yoon Suk-yeol

Ahn Cheol-soo withdrew from the campaign and endorsed Yoon Suk-yeol. The move was seen as a significant boost to Yoon's campaign.

## Attack against Song Young-gil

Song Young-gil, the leader of the Democratic Party, was attacked by a protester during a campaign rally. The attack raised concerns about the safety of the candidates and the campaign teams.

# Voting

The presidential election was held on March 9, 2022. The voting was held from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm, and the results were announced later that night.

# Exit Polls

Exit polls were conducted by several organizations to gauge public opinion on the candidates. The exit polls showed a close contest between Lee Jae-myung and Yoon Suk-yeol.

# Results

The results of the presidential election were as follows:

* Yoon Suk-yeol (People Power Party): 48.56%
* Lee Jae-myung (Democratic Party): 47.83%
* Sim Sang-jung (Justice Party): 2.37%
* Ahn Cheol-soo (People Party): 0.66%
* Oh Jun-ho (Basic Income Party): 0.15%
* Kim Min-gi (Minsaeng Party): 0.12%
* Kim Jae-jeon (Transition Korea): 0.08%
* Cho Won-jin (Our Republican Party): 0.06%
* Lee Gyeong-hee (Unification Democratic Party): 0.05%
* Ok Soo-ho (Minsaeng Party): 0.04%

## By Region

The results of the presidential election by region were as follows:

### Major Candidates

* Seoul: Yoon Suk-yeol (50.56%), Lee Jae-myung (46.71%)
* Busan: Yoon Suk-yeol (55.17%), Lee Jae-myung (40.53%)
* Incheon: Lee Jae-myung (50.15%), Yoon Suk-yeol (46.13%)
* Daegu: Yoon Suk-yeol (63.14%), Lee Jae-myung (32.45%)
* Daejeon: Lee Jae-myung (51.23%), Yoon Suk-yeol (44.31%)
* Gwangju: Lee Jae-myung (63.45%), Yoon Suk-yeol (31.24%)
* Ulsan: Yoon Suk-yeol (51.15%), Lee Jae-myung (43.55%)

### Minor Candidates

* Seoul: Sim Sang-jung (1.51%), Ahn Cheol-soo (0.63%)
* Busan: Sim Sang-jung (1.23%), Ahn Cheol-soo (0.51%)
* Incheon: Sim Sang-jung (1.42%), Ahn Cheol-soo (0.63%)
* Daegu: Sim Sang-jung (0.92%), Ahn Cheol-soo (0.41%)
* Daejeon: Sim Sang-jung (1.21%), Ahn Cheol-soo (0.56%)
* Gwangju: Sim Sang-jung (2.15%), Ahn Cheol-soo (0.73%)
* Ulsan: Sim Sang-jung (1.05%), Ahn Cheol-soo (0.51%)

# Aftermath

The presidential election was marked by a close contest between Lee Jae-myung and Yoon Suk-yeol. Yoon Suk-yeol was declared the winner, and he was inaugurated as the President of South Korea on May 10, 2022.

article:
Glossary of Climbing Terms

Climbing is a physically and mentally demanding sport that requires a unique set of skills, techniques, and equipment. Over the years, climbers have developed a specialized language to describe various aspects of the sport, from techniques and equipment to safety protocols and climbing styles. This glossary of climbing terms provides a comprehensive overview of the language used by climbers, covering a wide range of topics from A to Z.

#A

## Abseil
Abseiling is a technique used to descend a rope in a controlled manner, typically by using a device that slows down the rope's descent. Abseiling is often used in climbing, canyoneering, and rescue applications.

## Aid Climbing
Aid climbing is a type of climbing that involves using equipment such as ladders, hooks, and cams to ascend a route. Aid climbing is often used when free climbing is not possible due to the difficulty or danger of the route.

## Alpine Climbing
Alpine climbing is a type of climbing that involves ascending mountains using a combination of hiking, scrambling, and technical climbing techniques. Alpine climbing often involves traversing glaciers, snowfields, and exposed ridges.

## Anchor
An anchor is a secure point of attachment that is used to protect a climber from falling. Anchors can be natural, such as trees or rocks, or artificial, such as bolts or cams.

## Ascender
An ascender is a device used to climb a rope in a controlled manner. Ascenders are often used in aid climbing, canyoneering, and rescue applications.

#B

## Belay
Belaying is the act of controlling the rope during climbing, either by feeding it out as the climber ascends or by catching the climber if they fall. Belaying is a critical aspect of climbing safety.

## Bolt
A bolt is a type of artificial anchor that is used to protect a climber from falling. Bolts are typically made of metal and are inserted into the rock to provide a secure attachment point.

## Buttress
A buttress is a section of rock that protrudes from the main face of a cliff or mountain. Buttresses can provide a challenging and exposed climbing route.

#C

## Cam
A cam is a type of artificial anchor that is used to protect a climber from falling. Cams are typically made of metal and are inserted into cracks or pockets in the rock to provide a secure attachment point.

## Canyoneering
Canyoneering is a type of adventure sport that involves exploring canyons using a combination of hiking, climbing, and rappelling techniques. Canyoneering often involves traversing waterfalls, gorges, and other challenging terrain.

## Carabiner
A carabiner is a type of metal clip that is used to connect ropes, anchors, and other equipment. Carabiners are typically made of aluminum or steel and are designed to withstand heavy loads.

## Chalk
Chalk is a type of powder that is used by climbers to dry their hands and improve their grip on the rock. Chalk is typically made of magnesium carbonate and is an essential part of a climber's equipment.

#D

## Dyno
A dyno is a type of dynamic movement that is used in climbing to reach a distant handhold or foothold. Dynos involve a sudden and explosive movement, often requiring a high degree of strength and power.

## Descender
A descender is a device used to control the rope during rappelling or abseiling. Descenders are typically made of metal or plastic and are designed to provide a smooth and controlled descent.

#E

## Edging
Edging is a type of climbing technique that involves using the edges of the shoes to support the body on small footholds. Edging is often used on thin, slabby rock or on holds that are too small to support the entire foot.

## Exposure
Exposure refers to the degree of risk or danger involved in a particular climbing route or situation. Exposure can be physical, such as the risk of falling, or psychological, such as the fear of heights.

#F

## Face Climbing
Face climbing is a type of climbing that involves ascending a vertical or near-vertical rock face using a combination of handholds, footholds, and body positioning. Face climbing is often used on sport climbs and requires a high degree of strength, power, and technique.

## Fingerboard
A fingerboard is a type of training equipment used by climbers to improve their finger strength and dexterity. Fingerboards typically consist of a series of small holds or edges that are used to perform various exercises and movements.

## Foothold
A foothold is a small ledge or protrusion on the rock that is used to support the foot during climbing. Footholds can be natural or artificial and are often used in combination with handholds to ascend a route.

#G

## Gear
Gear refers to the equipment used by climbers, including ropes, harnesses, carabiners, and other hardware. Gear is an essential part of climbing and is used to protect the climber from falling and to facilitate movement on the rock.

## Grade
A grade is a measure of the difficulty of a particular climbing route. Grades can be numerical, such as the Yosemite Decimal System, or descriptive, such as the International French Adjectival System.

## Grip
Grip refers to the climber's hold on the rock, including the strength and security of their handholds and footholds. Grip is an essential aspect of climbing and is influenced by factors such as the type of rock, the weather, and the climber's technique.

#H

## Harness
A harness is a type of equipment used by climbers to attach themselves to the rope and to protect themselves from falling. Harnesses typically consist of a waist belt and leg loops and are designed to distribute the force of a fall across the climber's body.

## Handhold
A handhold is a small ledge or protrusion on the rock that is used to support the hand during climbing. Handholds can be natural or artificial and are often used in combination with footholds to ascend a route.

## Headwall
A headwall is a section of rock that is particularly steep or difficult to climb. Headwalls often require a high degree of strength, power, and technique to ascend.

#I

## Ice Axe
An ice axe is a type of equipment used by climbers to ascend and descend ice and snow. Ice axes typically consist of a metal head and a handle and are used to provide traction and balance on slippery surfaces.

## Ice Climbing
Ice climbing is a type of climbing that involves ascending ice formations using a combination of ice axes, crampons, and other equipment. Ice climbing is often used in alpine and winter climbing applications.

## In situ
In situ refers to a type of anchor that is already in place on the rock, such as a bolt or a piton. In situ anchors are often used by climbers to protect themselves from falling and to facilitate movement on the rock.

#J

## Jamming
Jamming is a type of climbing technique that involves using the hands, feet, or body to wedge oneself into a narrow crack or opening. Jamming is often used in aid climbing and requires a high degree of strength and endurance.

#K

## Knot
A knot is a type of fastening used to join two ropes together or to attach a rope to an anchor. Knots are an essential part of climbing and are used to provide a secure and reliable attachment point.

#L

## Layback
A layback is a type of climbing technique that involves leaning back and using the hands and feet to support the body on a vertical or near-vertical surface. Laybacks are often used on overhanging rock and require a high degree of strength and power.

## Lead Climbing
Lead climbing is a type of climbing that involves ascending a route while attaching oneself to the rope and anchors. Lead climbing is often used in sport climbing and requires a high degree of strength, power, and technique.

## Leg Loop
A leg loop is a type of equipment used by climbers to attach themselves to the rope and to protect themselves from falling. Leg loops are typically used in combination with a waist belt to form a harness.

#M

## Mantel
A mantel is a type of climbing technique that involves using the hands and feet to push oneself up and over a ledge or lip. Mantels are often used on overhanging rock and require a high degree of strength and power.

## Multi-Pitch Climbing
Multi-pitch climbing is a type of climbing that involves ascending a route in multiple sections or pitches. Multi-pitch climbing often requires a high degree of endurance and stamina and involves a variety of techniques and equipment.

#N

## Nut
A nut is a type of artificial anchor that is used to protect a climber from falling. Nuts are typically made of metal and are inserted into cracks or pockets in the rock to provide a secure attachment point.

#O

## Offwidth
An offwidth is a type of climbing route that involves ascending a wide crack or opening. Offwidths often require a high degree of strength and endurance and involve a variety of techniques and equipment.

## Onsight
An onsight is a type of climbing ascent that involves ascending a route without prior knowledge or experience of the route. Onsights are often used in competition climbing and require a high degree of skill and adaptability.

#P

## Pitch
A pitch is a section of a climbing route that is typically climbed in a single section or unit. Pitches can vary in length and difficulty and are often used to describe the layout and character of a route.

## Piton
A piton is a type of artificial anchor that is used to protect a climber from falling. Pitons are typically made of metal and are inserted into cracks or pockets in the rock to provide a secure attachment point.

## Protection
Protection refers to the equipment and techniques used by climbers to protect themselves from falling. Protection can include anchors, ropes, harnesses, and other hardware and is an essential aspect of climbing.

#Q

## Quickdraw
A quickdraw is a type of equipment used by climbers to connect the rope to an anchor or protection point. Quickdraws typically consist of a carabiner and a sling and are used to provide a quick and secure attachment point.

#R

## Rappel
A rappel is a type of controlled descent that involves using a rope to lower oneself down a vertical or near-vertical surface. Rappels are often used in climbing and canyoneering and require a high degree of skill and attention to safety.

## Rescue
A rescue is an operation that involves retrieving a climber or other person from a difficult or dangerous location. Rescues often require specialized equipment and techniques and involve a high degree of risk and complexity.

## Rock Shoe
A rock shoe is a type of footwear used by climbers to provide support and traction on the rock. Rock shoes are typically made of leather or synthetic materials and are designed to fit snugly around the foot.

#S

## Sling
A sling is a type of equipment used by climbers to connect the rope to an anchor or protection point. Slings are typically made of nylon or other materials and are used to provide a quick and secure attachment point.

## Sport Climbing
Sport climbing is a type of climbing that involves ascending a route using pre-drilled holes and permanent anchors. Sport climbing is often used in competition climbing and requires a high degree of strength, power, and technique.

## Static Rope
A static rope is a type of rope that is designed to absorb the shock of a fall without stretching or elongating. Static ropes are often used in climbing and rescue applications and are typically made of nylon or other materials.

#T

## Toprope
A toprope is a type of climbing setup that involves attaching the rope to an anchor at the top of the climb and then feeding it down to the climber. Topropes are often used in sport climbing and require a high degree of skill and attention to safety.

## Trad Climbing
Trad climbing is a type of climbing that involves ascending a route using natural anchors and protection points. Trad climbing often requires a high degree of skill and experience and involves a variety of techniques and equipment.

## Traverse
A traverse is a type of climbing movement that involves moving horizontally or diagonally across a rock face or surface. Traverses often require a high degree of balance and coordination and involve a variety of techniques and equipment.

#U

## Undercling
An undercling is a type of climbing hold that involves gripping the rock with the hands or feet in an underhand position. Underclings are often used on overhanging rock and require a high degree of strength and power.

#V

## Via Ferrata
A via ferrata is a type of climbing route that involves using iron rungs and cables to ascend a steep or difficult section of rock. Via ferratas are often used in alpine and sport climbing applications and require a high degree of skill and attention to safety.

#W

## Waist Belt
A waist belt is a type of equipment used by climbers to attach themselves to the rope and to protect themselves from falling. Waist belts are typically used in combination with leg loops to form a harness.

## Webbing
Webbing is a type of material used by climbers to create anchors and protection points. Webbing is typically made of nylon or other materials and is used to provide a quick and secure attachment point.

#X

## X-Anchor
An X-anchor is a type of anchor that involves using two or more anchors to create a secure attachment point. X-anchors are often used in climbing and rescue applications and require a high degree of skill and attention to safety.

#Y

## Yosemite Decimal System
The Yosemite Decimal System is a grading system used to measure the difficulty of climbing routes. The system uses a combination of numbers and letters to describe the difficulty of a route, from easy (Class 1) to extremely difficult (Class 5).

#Z

## Zigzag
A zigzag is a type of climbing movement that involves moving in a zigzag or diagonal pattern across a rock face or surface. Zigzags often require a high degree of balance and coordination and involve a variety of techniques and equipment.

#See also

* List of climbing equipment
* List of climbing techniques
* Glossary of caving terms
* Glossary of mountaineering terms

#References

* None

#External links

* American Mountain Guides Association
* International Federation of Mountain Guides Associations
* Union of International Alpine Associations

article:
2022 Fijian General Election

The 2022 Fijian general election was held on December 14, 2022, to elect the 55 members of the Parliament of Fiji. The election was the fourth since the country's return to democracy in 2014 and the second under the incumbent Prime Minister, Frank Bainimarama.

# Background

Fiji has a complex and often tumultuous history of elections, with the country experiencing four coups since independence in 1970. The 2018 general election saw the FijiFirst party, led by Frank Bainimarama, win a narrow victory over the opposition Social Democratic Liberal Party (SODELPA). The election was marked by allegations of electoral irregularities and concerns over the impartiality of the electoral commission.

In the lead-up to the 2022 election, Fiji experienced significant economic growth, but also faced challenges such as rising cost of living, unemployment, and natural disasters. The COVID-19 pandemic had a significant impact on the country's economy, with tourism, a major industry, experiencing a significant decline.

# Electoral System

Fiji uses a proportional representation system, where voters cast a single ballot for a candidate, and seats are allocated based on the number of votes received by each party.

## Voters

All Fijian citizens aged 18 and above, who are registered on the electoral roll, are eligible to vote. The electoral roll is compiled by the Fijian Elections Office, which is responsible for conducting the election.

## Electoral Changes

In 2020, the Fijian government introduced changes to the electoral laws, which included the introduction of a new voter registration system and changes to the electoral boundaries. The changes were aimed at improving the efficiency and integrity of the electoral process.

# Schedule

article:
Chris Sharma
================

Chris Sharma is a renowned American rock climber, entrepreneur, and environmental activist. Born on April 23, 1981, in Santa Cruz, California, Sharma is widely regarded as one of the most accomplished and influential climbers of his generation. With a career spanning over three decades, Sharma has established himself as a pioneer in the sport, pushing the boundaries of human potential and redefining the concept of what is possible on the rock.

Early Life
-----------

Sharma grew up in a supportive family that encouraged his passion for climbing from an early age. His parents, Bob and Gail Sharma, were both avid climbers who introduced Chris to the sport when he was just six years old. Sharma's natural talent, combined with his dedication and perseverance, quickly propelled him to the forefront of the climbing community.

Climbing Career
----------------

Sharma's climbing career can be divided into several distinct phases, each marked by significant achievements and innovations.

### 1996–2002 (to Realization)

Sharma's early career was marked by a string of impressive ascents, including the first free solo of the notorious "Nose" route on El Capitan in Yosemite Valley. In 2001, Sharma made the first ascent of "Realization" (also known as "Biographie") in Céüse, France, a route that would become a benchmark for climbers around the world.

### 2002–2008 (to Jumbo Love)

In the early 2000s, Sharma shifted his focus to sport climbing, exploring new destinations and establishing cutting-edge routes. In 2008, Sharma made the first ascent of "Jumbo Love" in Clark Mountain, California, a 250-foot (76 m) route that pushed the limits of human endurance and physicality.

### 2008–2013 (to La Dura Dura)

Sharma's next major project was "La Dura Dura" in Oliana, Spain, a route that would go on to become one of the most famous climbs in the world. Sharma spent several years working on the route, eventually completing the first ascent in 2013.

### Post 2013

Since completing "La Dura Dura," Sharma has continued to explore new destinations and establish innovative routes. In 2017, Sharma made the first ascent of "El Bon Combat" in Cuenca, Spain, a route that marked a new era in sport climbing.

Legacy
--------

Chris Sharma's impact on the world of climbing cannot be overstated. Through his pioneering ascents and advocacy for environmental sustainability, Sharma has inspired a generation of climbers to push the boundaries of human potential and explore new frontiers. Sharma's commitment to protecting the natural world has also led to the establishment of the Sharma Fund, a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting environmental conservation and sustainability.

Personal Life
--------------

### Zen

Sharma has spoken publicly about the importance of Zen Buddhism in his life, citing its influence on his approach to climbing and his personal philosophy. Sharma has also incorporated elements of Zen into his business ventures, including his clothing company, Sharma Climbing.

Notable Ascents
----------------

### Redpointed Routes

* "Realization" (Biographie), Céüse, France (2001)
* "Jumbo Love," Clark Mountain, California (2008)
* "La Dura Dura," Oliana, Spain (2013)
* "El Bon Combat," Cuenca, Spain (2017)

### Onsighted Routes

* "Nose," El Capitan, Yosemite Valley (1996)
* "Freerider," El Capitan, Yosemite Valley (1998)

### Deep-Water Solo Routes

* "Es Pontas," Mallorca, Spain (2003)
* "The Needle," El Potrero Chico, Mexico (2005)

### Boulder Problems

* "The Game," Rocky Mountain National Park, Colorado (2005)
* "Practice of the Wild," Rocky Mountain National Park, Colorado (2006)

Bibliography
-------------

* Sharma, Chris. (2005). "The Climbing Life." Patagonia Books.
* Sharma, Chris. (2011). "The Dirtbag Diaries." Patagonia Books.

Filmography
------------

* "Dosage" (2001)
* "King Lines" (2007)
* "The Wildest Dream" (2010)
* "Reel Rock 7" (2012)

Competitions
------------

* 1997: Winner, Bouldering World Cup, Munich, Germany
* 2000: Winner, Climbing World Championships, Birmingham, UK

---------

article:
James (2022 film)

James is a 2022 Indian Kannada-language action drama film written and directed by Chethan Kumar. The film stars Puneeth Rajkumar, Priya Anand, and Sarath Kumar in lead roles. It was released on March 17, 2022, and marked the final film appearance of Puneeth Rajkumar before his death.

# Plot

The film tells the story of James, a former soldier who returns to his hometown to live a peaceful life. However, his tranquility is short-lived as he is drawn into a world of violence and corruption. James must confront his past demons and take on the villains to protect his family and community.

The film's narrative is layered with themes of patriotism, loyalty, and the struggles of the common man. The protagonist, James, is a symbol of hope and courage in the face of adversity. Through his journey, the film highlights the importance of standing up against injustice and fighting for what is right.

# Cast

* Puneeth Rajkumar as James
* Priya Anand as Nisha
* Sarath Kumar as Satya
* Anu Prabhakar as James's mother
* R. Sarathkumar as James's father
* Aditya Menon as the main antagonist
* Srikanth as a supporting antagonist
* Sadhu Kokila as a comic relief

# Production

## Casting

The film's casting process began in 2020, with Puneeth Rajkumar being the first to be cast as the lead. Priya Anand was cast as the female lead, and Sarath Kumar was brought on board to play a key supporting role. The film's antagonist was played by Aditya Menon, who is known for his villainous roles in Kannada cinema.

## Filming

Principal photography for the film began in January 2021 and lasted for several months. The film was shot on location in Bangalore, Mysore, and other parts of Karnataka. The film's action sequences were choreographed by stunt master Ravi Varma.

The film's director, Chethan Kumar, worked closely with the cast and crew to ensure that the film's vision was realized. He took inspiration from real-life incidents and incorporated them into the film's narrative.

# Music

The film's soundtrack was composed by V. Harikrishna, who is known for his work in Kannada cinema. The film's score was a mix of energetic and emotional tracks, reflecting the film's themes and tone.

The film's songs were well-received by audiences and critics alike. The title track, "James," became a chart-topper, and other songs like "Nee Parichaya" and "Yaare Yaare" were also popular.

# Release

## Theatrical

The film was released on March 17, 2022, in theaters across Karnataka. The film received a grand opening, with many shows selling out in advance. The film's release was marked by fanfare, with fans gathering outside theaters to catch a glimpse of the film's stars.

The film was released in over 500 theaters across Karnataka, making it one of the widest releases in the state. The film's distributor, Jayanna Films, worked closely with the film's producers to ensure a smooth release.

## Re-release

Due to popular demand, the film was re-released in several theaters across Karnataka in April 2022. The re-release was marked by a special promotional campaign, with the film's stars attending fan events and promoting the film on social media.

## Home media

The film was released on digital platforms in May 2022, making it available to audiences worldwide. The film's digital release was marked by a special promotional campaign, with the film's stars promoting the film on social media.

# Reception

## Critical response

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with many praising the film's action sequences and performances. However, some critics felt that the film's narrative was predictable and lacked depth.

The film's lead actor, Puneeth Rajkumar, received widespread praise for his performance. Critics noted that he brought a level of depth and nuance to the film's protagonist, making him relatable and rootable.

## Box office

The film was a commercial success, grossing over ₹100 crore at the box office. The film's success was attributed to its strong word-of-mouth and positive reviews from critics.

The film's success was also attributed to the popularity of its lead actor, Puneeth Rajkumar. Fans flocked to theaters to catch a glimpse of the actor, who was known for his charisma and screen presence.

article:
Tartan
=======

Tartan is a specific type of woven plaid textile that originated in Scotland, characterized by its distinctive crisscross patterns of color. The term "tartan" has become synonymous with Scottish culture and heritage, and its intricate designs have captivated people around the world. From its humble beginnings as a practical fabric for everyday use to its current status as a symbol of Scottish identity, tartan has evolved over the centuries to become an integral part of Scotland's rich cultural tapestry.

Etymology and Terminology
-------------------------

The word "tartan" is derived from the French word "tartane," which refers to a type of woolen cloth. In Scotland, the term "tartan" was initially used to describe the fabric itself, rather than the specific patterns woven into it. Over time, however, the term has come to be associated with the distinctive plaid patterns that have become iconic of Scottish culture.

Weaving and Design
-----------------

### Weaving Construction

Tartan is woven using a specific type of loom called a "tappet loom." This type of loom allows the weaver to create complex patterns by raising and lowering the warp threads in a specific sequence. The warp threads are typically made of wool, while the weft threads can be made of wool, cotton, or other materials.

### Styles and Design Principles

There are several different styles of tartan, each with its own unique characteristics and design principles. Some of the most common styles include:

* **Symmetrical tartans**: These are the most common type of tartan, featuring symmetrical patterns that repeat on both sides of the center line.
* **Asymmetrical tartans**: These tartans feature patterns that are not symmetrical, often with different colors and motifs on either side of the center line.
* **Reversing tartans**: These tartans feature patterns that reverse on either side of the center line, often creating a mirror-like effect.

### Colour, Palettes, and Meaning

Tartans are characterized by their distinctive color palettes, which can vary greatly depending on the specific design. Some tartans feature bright, bold colors, while others are more subdued and muted. The colors used in tartan designs often have specific meanings and associations, such as:

* **Red**: symbolizing courage and bravery
* **Blue**: symbolizing loyalty and fidelity
* **Green**: symbolizing nature and the outdoors
* **Yellow**: symbolizing sunshine and optimism

Early History
-------------

### Pre-medieval Origins

The earliest evidence of tartan-like textiles dates back to the Iron Age, with examples of woven plaid fabrics found in ancient Celtic burial sites. These early textiles were likely made using simple looms and were used for everyday clothing and other practical purposes.

### Medieval

During the medieval period, tartan became a staple of Scottish culture, with different clans and families developing their own unique tartan patterns. These early tartans were often made using natural dyes and were used for a variety of purposes, including clothing, blankets, and other textiles.

### 16th century

The 16th century saw the rise of the Scottish textile industry, with tartan becoming a major export commodity. This period also saw the development of new tartan designs and patterns, often featuring intricate and complex motifs.

### 17th century

Bibliography of the United States Constitution

The United States Constitution has been the subject of extensive research and analysis since its adoption in 1787. This bibliography is a comprehensive list of publications that have contributed to our understanding of the Constitution, its history, and its impact on American society. The following sections provide an overview of the key publications in the 18th, 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries, as well as primary sources, works influential to the Founders, and notable scholars such as James Madison.

# Preliminary notes

The study of the United States Constitution is a vast and complex field, with new research and analysis emerging continuously. This bibliography aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the key publications in the field, but it is not exhaustive. The sections that follow are organized chronologically, with a focus on major publications, journals, and primary sources.

# 18th century publications

The 18th century saw the publication of several key works related to the United States Constitution. One of the most influential was "The Federalist Papers," a series of essays written by Alexander Hamilton, James Madison, and John Jay in 1787-1788. These essays were published in various newspapers and later compiled into a single volume, providing a detailed explanation of the Constitution's provisions and the reasoning behind them.

Other notable 18th-century publications include "The Anti-Federalist Papers," a collection of essays written by opponents of the Constitution, and "The Debates in the Federal Convention of 1787," which provides a detailed account of the Constitutional Convention.

## Journals 1

Several journals were established in the 18th century to provide a forum for discussion and debate about the Constitution. These include:

* The Pennsylvania Magazine, which published several essays on the Constitution in 1787-1788.
* The American Museum, which published a series of essays on the Constitution in 1787.
* The Columbian Magazine, which published several articles on the Constitution in 1787-1788.

# 19th century publications

The 19th century saw a significant increase in publications related to the United States Constitution. One of the most influential works of this period was "Commentaries on the Constitution of the United States" by Joseph Story, published in 1833. This three-volume work provides a detailed analysis of the Constitution's provisions and their application in American law.

Other notable 19th-century publications include "The Constitutional Law of the United States" by Thomas Cooley, published in 1880, and "The American Commonwealth" by James Bryce, published in 1888.

## Journals 2

Several journals were established in the 19th century to provide a forum for discussion and debate about the Constitution. These include:

* The North American Review, which published several articles on the Constitution in the 1820s-1830s.
* The American Law Register, which published several articles on constitutional law in the 1850s-1860s.
* The Harvard Law Review, which was established in 1887 and has since become one of the leading journals of constitutional law in the United States.

# 20th century publications

The 20th century saw a significant increase in research and analysis of the United States Constitution. One of the most influential works of this period was "The Supreme Court in the American System of Government" by Robert McCloskey, published in 1960. This book provides a detailed analysis of the Supreme Court's role in interpreting the Constitution.

Other notable 20th-century publications include "The Constitution of the United States: A Critical Discussion of Its Genesis, Formulation, and Program" by Hans Kelsen, published in 1945, and "The American Constitution: Its Origins and Development" by Alfred Kelly and Winfred Harbison, published in 1963.

## Journals 3

Several journals were established in the 20th century to provide a forum for discussion and debate about the Constitution. These include:

* The Yale Law Journal, which published several articles on constitutional law in the 1920s-1930s.
* The University of Chicago Law Review, which was established in 1933 and has since become one of the leading journals of constitutional law in the United States.
* The Constitutional Commentary, which was established in 1984 and provides a forum for discussion and debate about the Constitution.

# 21st century publications

The 21st century has seen a significant increase in research and analysis of the United States Constitution. One of the most influential works of this period is "The Oxford Handbook of the United States Constitution" edited by Michael Stokes Paulsen, Steven G. Calabresi, and Christopher S. Yoo, published in 2015. This book provides a comprehensive overview of the Constitution's history, provisions, and application in American law.

Other notable 21st-century publications include "The Cambridge Companion to the United States Constitution" edited by Michael Stokes Paulsen, Steven G. Calabresi, and Christopher S. Yoo, published in 2006, and "The Constitution in Wartime: Beyond Alarmism and Complacency" edited by Mark Tushnet, published in 2005.

## Journals 4

Several journals have been established in the 21st century to provide a forum for discussion and debate about the Constitution. These include:

* The Constitutional Law Journal, which was established in 2005 and provides a forum for discussion and debate about constitutional law.
* The Journal of Constitutional Law, which was established in 2007 and provides a forum for discussion and debate about constitutional law.
* The American Constitution Society for Law and Policy, which was established in 2001 and provides a forum for discussion and debate about constitutional law and policy.

# Primary sources

Primary sources are essential for understanding the United States Constitution and its history. These include:

## Works influential to the Founders

The Founders were influenced by several key works, including:

* "The Social Contract" by Jean-Jacques Rousseau, published in 1762.
* "The Spirit of the Laws" by Montesquieu, published in 1748.
* "The Wealth of Nations" by Adam Smith, published in 1776.

# James Madison

James Madison was one of the key Founders and drafters of the United States Constitution. His papers and correspondence provide valuable insights into the Constitution's history and meaning.

## Journals 4

Several journals have been established to provide a forum for discussion and debate about James Madison and his role in the Constitution's history. These include:

* The James Madison Papers, which were published in the 1960s and provide a comprehensive overview of Madison's papers and correspondence.
* The Papers of James Madison, which were published in the 1980s and provide a comprehensive overview of Madison's papers and correspondence.

## Madison correspondence

Madison's correspondence provides valuable insights into the Constitution's history and meaning. His correspondence with other key Founders, including Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton, is particularly significant.

# Slavery and the Constitution

Slavery was a significant issue in the Constitution's history, and its legacy continues to shape American society today.

## Journals 5

Several journals have been established to provide a forum for discussion and debate about slavery and the Constitution. These include:

* The Journal of the Early Republic, which published several articles on slavery and the Constitution in the 1980s-1990s.
* The William and Mary Quarterly, which published several articles on slavery and the Constitution in the 1990s-2000s.
* The Journal of African American History, which published several articles on slavery and the Constitution in the 2000s-2010s.

# Notes

article:
2022 Conservative Party of Canada Leadership Election

The 2022 Conservative Party of Canada leadership election was a leadership election held by the Conservative Party of Canada to elect a new leader. The election was triggered by the resignation of Erin O'Toole as party leader on February 2, 2022. The contest was won by Pierre Poilievre, a Member of Parliament from Ontario, who was elected as the new leader of the Conservative Party.

# Background

The Conservative Party of Canada had been led by Erin O'Toole since August 2020. However, O'Toole's leadership was marked by controversy and criticism from within the party, particularly from the party's right wing. In January 2022, O'Toole faced a confidence vote by the party's caucus, which he won by a narrow margin. However, the vote was seen as a sign of weakness, and O'Toole ultimately resigned as party leader on February 2, 2022.

# Timeline

## 2020

* August 2020: Erin O'Toole is elected as the leader of the Conservative Party of Canada.

## 2021

* January 2021: O'Toole faces criticism from within the party for his handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.
* June 2021: O'Toole is criticized for his response to the discovery of unmarked graves at a former residential school in Kamloops, British Columbia.
* November 2021: O'Toole faces a non-confidence vote by the party's caucus, which he wins by a narrow margin.

## 2022

* February 2, 2022: Erin O'Toole resigns as leader of the Conservative Party of Canada.
* February 5, 2022: The Conservative Party's National Council sets the rules and timeline for the leadership election.
* May 2022: The first debate is held among the leadership candidates.
* June 2022: The second debate is held among the leadership candidates.
* July 2022: The membership sales deadline is reached, and the party announces that over 600,000 members have been sold.
* August 2022: The final debate is held among the leadership candidates.
* September 10, 2022: The leadership election is held, and Pierre Poilievre is elected as the new leader of the Conservative Party.

# Rules and Procedures

The rules and procedures for the leadership election were set by the Conservative Party's National Council. The election was held using a ranked-choice voting system, where members ranked their preferred candidates in order of preference. The candidate with the fewest first-choice votes was eliminated in each round, and their supporters' second-choice votes were redistributed to the remaining candidates. The process continued until one candidate had a majority of the votes.

# Campaign

The campaign for the leadership election was marked by a series of debates among the candidates. The debates were held in May, June, and August 2022, and were broadcast on television and online.

## Aftermath

The leadership election was won by Pierre Poilievre, who was elected as the new leader of the Conservative Party. Poilievre's victory was seen as a shift to the right for the party, and he has promised to take a more aggressive approach to opposing the Liberal government.

# Results

The results of the leadership election were as follows:

* Pierre Poilievre: 68.15%
* Jean Charest: 16.07%
* Leslyn Lewis: 9.69%
* Roman Baber: 5.53%
* Scott Aitchison: 0.56%

## Provincial Summary

The results of the leadership election were broken down by province as follows:

* Alberta: Pierre Poilievre (74.15%)
* British Columbia: Pierre Poilievre (63.15%)
* Ontario: Pierre Poilievre (65.15%)
* Quebec: Jean Charest (43.07%)
* Nova Scotia: Pierre Poilievre (61.15%)
* New Brunswick: Pierre Poilievre (59.15%)
* Prince Edward Island: Pierre Poilievre (56.15%)
* Newfoundland and Labrador: Pierre Poilievre (53.15%)

# Debates

A series of debates were held among the leadership candidates during the campaign. The debates were broadcast on television and online, and were moderated by journalists and party officials.

# Candidates

## Disqualified

* Patrick Brown

## Withdrew or failed to qualify

### Failed to qualify as verified contestants

## Declined

The following individuals declined to run for the leadership of the Conservative Party:

* Rona Ambrose

# Endorsements

The following individuals and organizations endorsed candidates in the leadership election:

* Pierre Poilievre: endorsed by Jason Kenney, Doug Ford, and the Canadian Taxpayers Federation
* Jean Charest: endorsed by Rona Ambrose, Michael Chong, and the Canadian Chamber of Commerce
* Leslyn Lewis: endorsed by Campaign Life Coalition and the Canada Christian College
* Roman Baber: endorsed by the Jewish Defence League
* Scott Aitchison: endorsed by the Ontario Federation of Agriculture

# Membership sales

The Conservative Party sold over 600,000 memberships during the leadership election, with the majority being sold in the final weeks of the campaign.

# Fundraising

The candidates raised the following amounts of money during the leadership election:

# Opinion polling

## Conservative Party supporters

A series of polls were conducted among Conservative Party supporters during the leadership election. The results were as follows:

article:
Jean-Luc Godard is a French-Swiss film director, screenwriter, and film critic known for his innovative and provocative style, which has had a significant influence on the development of modern cinema. Born on December 3, 1930, in Paris, France, Godard has been a key figure in the French New Wave movement and has continued to produce influential films throughout his career.

# Early life

Godard was born into a wealthy family in the 7th arrondissement of Paris. His father, Paul Godard, was a Swiss doctor, and his mother, Odile Monod, was a French socialite. Godard's family moved to Switzerland when he was four years old, and he spent much of his childhood in Nyon, Switzerland. Godard's early life was marked by a love of literature and philosophy, and he was particularly influenced by the works of Jean-Jacques Rousseau and Friedrich Nietzsche.

# Early career (1950–1959)

## Film criticism

Godard began his career in film as a critic, writing for the Cahiers du Cinéma, a French film magazine that was a key platform for the French New Wave movement. Godard's criticism was known for its intellectual rigor and its emphasis on the importance of film as an art form. He was particularly influenced by the works of André Bazin, a French film critic who argued that film should be valued for its unique aesthetic qualities rather than its ability to tell stories.

## Filmmaking

In the late 1950s, Godard began to make his own films, starting with a series of short films that were heavily influenced by the Italian Neorealist movement. Godard's early films were marked by their use of location shooting and their focus on everyday life. His first feature film, "Breathless," was released in 1960 and was a major success, both critically and commercially.

# New Wave period (1960–1967)

## Breathless

"Breathless" was a groundbreaking film that marked a significant departure from traditional French cinema. The film's use of handheld camera work, location shooting, and improvisation created a sense of spontaneity and freedom that was new to French cinema. The film's story, which follows a car thief and his American girlfriend as they flee Paris, was also innovative in its use of non-linear narrative and its emphasis on the emotional lives of its characters.

## Early work with Anna Karina

Godard's collaboration with actress Anna Karina marked a significant period in his career. Karina, who was also Godard's wife, appeared in several of his films, including "Le petit soldat" and "Vivre sa vie." Karina's performances were marked by their intensity and vulnerability, and she became a key figure in the French New Wave movement.

## Vivre sa vie

"Vivre sa vie" was released in 1962 and was a major success, both critically and commercially. The film's story, which follows a young woman who becomes a prostitute, was innovative in its use of non-linear narrative and its emphasis on the emotional lives of its characters. The film's use of long takes and location shooting also created a sense of realism and immediacy.

## Le petit soldat and Les Carabiniers

"Le petit soldat" and "Les Carabiniers" were released in 1960 and 1963, respectively, and marked a significant departure from Godard's earlier work. Both films were more overtly political than Godard's earlier work, and they marked a significant shift towards a more radical and experimental style.

## Contempt

"Contempt" was released in 1963 and was a major success, both critically and commercially. The film's story, which follows a screenwriter who becomes embroiled in a love triangle, was innovative in its use of non-linear narrative and its emphasis on the emotional lives of its characters. The film's use of long takes and location shooting also created a sense of realism and immediacy.

## Anouchka Films

In the mid-1960s, Godard founded Anouchka Films, a production company that was dedicated to producing innovative and experimental films. Anouchka Films produced several of Godard's films, including "Contempt" and "Pierrot le Fou."

## Week End

"Week End" was released in 1967 and marked a significant departure from Godard's earlier work. The film's story, which follows a young couple who embark on a road trip, was innovative in its use of non-linear narrative and its emphasis on the emotional lives of its characters. The film's use of long takes and location shooting also created a sense of realism and immediacy.

# Political period (1968–1979)

## Vietnam War

Godard's opposition to the Vietnam War marked a significant period in his career. Godard was a vocal critic of the war, and he produced several films that were critical of American foreign policy.

## Bertolt Brecht

Godard's work was heavily influenced by the German playwright Bertolt Brecht, who argued that art should be used as a tool for social change. Godard's films from this period were marked by their use of Brechtian alienation techniques, which were designed to distance the audience from the action on screen.

## Marxism

Godard's work was also heavily influenced by Marxist theory, which emphasized the importance of class struggle and the need for social change. Godard's films from this period were marked by their emphasis on the lives of working-class people and their struggles against oppression.

## Revolutionary period (1968–1979)

Godard's work from this period was marked by its emphasis on revolution and social change. Godard produced several films that were critical of capitalism and the bourgeoisie, and he was a vocal supporter of the student-led protests of 1968.

## Films

Godard's films from this period include "One Plus One," "British Sounds," and "Tout Va Bien." These films were marked by their use of experimental techniques and their emphasis on the lives of working-class people.

## Sonimage

In the 1970s, Godard founded Sonimage, a production company that was dedicated to producing experimental and innovative films. Sonimage produced several of Godard's films, including "Ici et ailleurs" and "Numéro deux."

## Jean-Pierre Gorin

Godard's collaboration with Jean-Pierre Gorin marked a significant period in his career. Gorin, who was also a film director, worked with Godard on several films, including "Ici et ailleurs" and "Tout Va Bien."

## Dziga Vertov Group

Godard was a member of the Dziga Vertov Group, a collective of filmmakers who were dedicated to producing experimental and innovative films. The group was named after the Soviet filmmaker Dziga Vertov, who was known for his innovative use of montage techniques.

# Return to commercial films and Histoire(s) du cinéma (1980–2000)

In the 1980s, Godard returned to making commercial films, including "Sauve qui peut (la vie)" and "Détective." Godard also began work on his ambitious project, "Histoire(s) du cinéma," which was a eight-part series of films that explored the history of cinema.

# Late period films (2001–2022)

Godard's late period films include "In Praise of Love," "Notre musique," and "Adieu au langage." These films were marked by their use of experimental techniques and their emphasis on the role of cinema in contemporary society.

# Personal life and death

Godard was married to actress Anna Karina from 1961 to 1965, and he had a daughter, Eugénie, with his second wife, Anne-Marie Miéville. Godard died on September 13, 2022, at the age of 91.

# Legacy

Godard's legacy is complex and multifaceted. He is widely regarded as one of the most influential filmmakers of the 20th century, and his innovative use of camera techniques, editing, and narrative structure has influenced generations of filmmakers. Godard's emphasis on the importance of cinema as an art form has also had a significant impact on film theory and criticism.

# Collaboration with ECM Records

In the 1980s, Godard collaborated with the German record label ECM Records on several projects, including the soundtracks for his films "Sauve qui peut (la vie)" and "Détective."

article:
Shane Warne

Shane Keith Warne (13 September 1969 – 4 March 2022) was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as one of the greatest bowlers in the history of the game. He played for the Australian national team from 1992 to 2007 and was a key member of the team that dominated international cricket during the 1990s and early 2000s.

# Early life

Warne was born in Upper Ferntree Gully, Victoria, Australia, to Keith and Brigitte Warne. He grew up in a sporting family and was introduced to cricket at a young age by his father. Warne attended Hampton High School and later studied at Mentone Grammar School, where he developed his cricket skills. He was a talented junior cricketer and represented Victoria at the under-16 and under-19 levels.

# Early career

Warne began his cricket career as a right-arm medium-pace bowler but later developed into a leg-spin bowler. He made his first-class debut for Victoria in 1991 and quickly established himself as a talented young bowler. Warne's unique bowling style, which included a distinctive action and a wide range of variations, caught the attention of Australian selectors, and he was soon called up to the national team.

# Domestic career

Warne played domestic cricket for Victoria from 1991 to 2007 and was a key member of the team that won several Sheffield Shield titles. He also played for the Australian Cricket Academy and the Australian XI in various matches. Warne's domestic career was marked by his exceptional bowling performances, which earned him numerous awards and accolades.

# International career

## Early international career (1992–1995)

Warne made his international debut for Australia in 1992 in a Test match against Sri Lanka. He took 1/11 in his first innings and went on to take 16 wickets in the series. Warne's early international career was marked by his consistent performances, which earned him a place in the Australian team. He played in several Test series and One-Day Internationals (ODIs) and quickly established himself as a key member of the team.

## West Indies tour, Cricket World Cup and injury (1995–1999)

In 1995, Warne toured the West Indies with the Australian team and took 15 wickets in the series. He also played in the 1996 Cricket World Cup, where Australia reached the final, and took 12 wickets in the tournament. However, Warne's career was interrupted by a series of injuries, including a shoulder injury that required surgery. He missed several matches and was out of the team for several months.

## Vice-captaincy of Australia (1999–2000)

In 1999, Warne was appointed vice-captain of the Australian team under Steve Waugh. He played a key role in the team's success during this period, taking 29 wickets in the 1999 Ashes series and 24 wickets in the 2000 Test series against India.

## Wickets and injuries (2001–2003)

Warne continued to take wickets consistently throughout his career, but he was also plagued by injuries. In 2001, he took 34 wickets in the Ashes series, but he also suffered a shoulder injury that required surgery. Warne missed several matches and was out of the team for several months.

## Ban from cricket (2003)

In 2003, Warne was banned from cricket for 12 months after testing positive for a banned diuretic. He was found to have taken a fluid tablet given to him by his mother, which contained a banned substance. Warne denied intentionally taking the substance, but he was still banned from cricket.

## Return to cricket and beyond 600 Test wickets (2004–2006)

Warne returned to cricket in 2004 and quickly established himself as one of the best bowlers in the world. He took 26 wickets in the 2004 Ashes series and 40 wickets in the 2005 Ashes series. Warne also became the first bowler to take 600 Test wickets, achieving the milestone in 2005.

## Later international career, 700th Test wicket and retirement (2006–2007)

Warne continued to play international cricket until 2007, taking 96 wickets in his last 18 Test matches. He also became the first bowler to take 700 Test wickets, achieving the milestone in 2006. Warne announced his retirement from international cricket in 2007, finishing his career with 708 wickets in 145 Test matches.

# Twenty20 career (2008–2013)

Warne played Twenty20 cricket for the Rajasthan Royals in the Indian Premier League (IPL) from 2008 to 2011. He was the captain of the team and led them to victory in the inaugural season of the IPL. Warne also played for the Melbourne Stars in the Big Bash League (BBL) from 2011 to 2013.

# Playing style

Warne was a leg-spin bowler who was known for his unique action and wide range of variations. He was a master of the "flipper," a delivery that skids quickly off the pitch, and the "googly," a delivery that turns from the off side to the leg side. Warne was also known for his ability to bowl long spells and take wickets consistently throughout his career.

# Performance analysis

## Test matches

Warne played 145 Test matches for Australia, taking 708 wickets at an average of 25.41. He took 37 five-wicket hauls and 10 ten-wicket hauls in Test matches.

# Commentator

Warne worked as a cricket commentator for Sky Sports and Fox Sports after his retirement from cricket. He was known for his insightful commentary and was widely respected by his peers.

# Personal life

Warne was married to Simone Callahan from 1995 to 2007. He had three children with Callahan: Brooke, Jackson, and Summer. Warne was known for his love of poker and was a regular participant in celebrity poker tournaments.

# Death

Warne died on 4 March 2022 at the age of 52 due to a heart attack while on holiday in Thailand.

## Tributes

Warne was remembered by his peers and fans as one of the greatest bowlers in the history of cricket. Tributes poured in from around the world, with many cricketers and celebrities paying their respects to Warne on social media.

## State memorial service

A state memorial service was held for Warne at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG) on 30 March 2022. The service was attended by Warne's family, friends, and former teammates, as well as thousands of fans.

# Awards

Warne was awarded the Allan Border Medal in 2000 and the Wisden Leading Cricketer in the World award in 1997. He was also inducted into the ICC Cricket Hall of Fame in 2013.

# In popular culture

Warne was featured in several documentaries and films, including "Shane" (2008) and "Shane Warne: The Musical" (2009). He also appeared in several television shows, including "I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!" (2016).

Vikrant Rona is a 2022 Indian Kannada-language action-adventure film written and directed by Anup Bhandari. The film stars Sudeep, Nirup Bhandari, and Neetha Ashok in lead roles. Vikrant Rona is a visually stunning and action-packed film that follows the story of a police officer who must solve a series of mysterious events in a remote village.

# Plot

The film takes place in the fictional town of Kamusutra, where a series of mysterious events unfolds. The story begins with the arrival of Vikrant Rona (Sudeep), a police officer who is tasked with investigating a series of bizarre incidents in the town. As Vikrant delves deeper into the mystery, he discovers that the events are all connected to an ancient legend about a powerful entity that is said to reside in the town.

As Vikrant gets closer to the truth, he faces numerous challenges and obstacles, including a group of rogue police officers who are determined to stop him. Along the way, he meets a local journalist, Sanju (Nirup Bhandari), who helps him unravel the mystery. Together, they discover that the entity is a powerful being that has been awakened by human activities in the town.

The film's plot is full of twists and turns, keeping the audience engaged and guessing until the very end. With its unique blend of action, adventure, and supernatural elements, Vikrant Rona is a thrilling ride that will keep viewers on the edge of their seats.

# Cast

* Sudeep as Vikrant Rona
* Nirup Bhandari as Sanju
* Neetha Ashok as Aparna
* Ravishankar Gowda as Rangappa
* Madhusudhan Rao as Lobo
* Dushara Vijayan as Janaki
* Chitkala Biradar as Girija
* Vasuki Vaibhav as Rajan

# Production

## Development

The idea for Vikrant Rona was conceptualized by Anup Bhandari, who wrote and directed the film. Bhandari is a well-known director in the Kannada film industry, having directed several successful films in the past. He was inspired by the idea of creating a film that would blend action, adventure, and supernatural elements.

Bhandari spent several years developing the script, working closely with his team to create a unique and engaging story. He drew inspiration from various sources, including mythology, folklore, and real-life events.

## Filming

Principal photography for Vikrant Rona began in March 2020 and was completed in December 2020. The film was shot on location in various parts of Karnataka, including Bengaluru, Mysuru, and Shivamogga.

The film's cinematography was handled by William David, who used a combination of camera techniques and visual effects to create a stunning visual experience. The action sequences in the film were choreographed by Anbariv, who is known for his work in several Indian films.

## Casting

The casting process for Vikrant Rona began in 2019, with Sudeep being the first actor to be cast in the lead role. Nirup Bhandari and Neetha Ashok were later cast in supporting roles.

Sudeep is a well-known actor in the Kannada film industry, having appeared in several successful films in the past. He was drawn to the project because of the unique storyline and the opportunity to play a complex character.

Nirup Bhandari is a talented young actor who has appeared in several Kannada films. He was cast in the role of Sanju, a local journalist who helps Vikrant unravel the mystery.

Neetha Ashok is a popular actress in the Kannada film industry, known for her performances in several films. She was cast in the role of Aparna, a key character in the story.

# Music

The music for Vikrant Rona was composed by B. Ajaneesh Loknath, who is known for his work in several Indian films. The soundtrack features a combination of energetic and soulful tracks, including the hit single "Lullaby".

The lyrics for the songs were written by Yogaraj Bhat, who is a well-known lyricist in the Kannada film industry. The music was performed by a range of talented artists, including Sudeep and Nirup Bhandari.

# Release

## Theatrical

Vikrant Rona was released in theaters on July 28, 2022. The film received a wide release, with over 1,000 screens in India and abroad.

The film's marketing campaign was handled by the film's production team, who used a range of promotional strategies to generate buzz around the film. The trailer for the film was released in June 2022 and received a huge response from fans.

## Distribution

The distribution rights for Vikrant Rona were acquired by KRG Studios, a well-known film distribution company in India. The film was released in several languages, including Kannada, Hindi, Tamil, and Telugu.

## Home media

Vikrant Rona was released on home media platforms in October 2022. The film is available on DVD, Blu-ray, and digital platforms, including Amazon Prime Video and Hotstar.

# Reception

## Critical reception

Vikrant Rona received positive reviews from critics, who praised the film's unique storyline, stunning visuals, and impressive performances. The film holds a rating of 7.5/10 on IMDB, based on over 10,000 user reviews.

Several critics praised Sudeep's performance in the lead role, calling it one of his best performances to date. Nirup Bhandari and Neetha Ashok also received praise for their supporting performances.

## Box office

Vikrant Rona was a commercial success, grossing over ₹100 crore at the box office worldwide. The film performed well in India and abroad, with a strong opening weekend and sustained collections throughout its run.

The film's success can be attributed to its unique storyline, stunning visuals, and impressive performances. The film's marketing campaign also played a key role in generating buzz around the film.

# Sequel

A sequel to Vikrant Rona is reportedly in development, with Anup Bhandari set to write and direct the film. The sequel is expected to continue the story of Vikrant Rona, with Sudeep reprising his role in the lead.

Details about the sequel are scarce, but fans are eagerly awaiting the announcement of a release date. The sequel is expected to be just as action-packed and thrilling as the original film.

# Awards

Vikrant Rona won several awards at the 2022 South Indian International Movie Awards, including Best Film, Best Director, and Best Actor for Sudeep.

The film also won several other awards, including the Best Film award at the 2022 Karnataka State Film Awards.

# Notes

Vikrant Rona is a unique and thrilling film that blends action, adventure, and supernatural elements. The film features stunning visuals, impressive performances, and a unique storyline that will keep viewers engaged until the very end.

The film's success can be attributed to the hard work and dedication of the cast and crew, who worked tirelessly to bring the story to life.

Collaboration with Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy

Collaboration with the Axis powers during World War II was a widespread phenomenon in Europe, with various forms of cooperation and support for the Nazi and Fascist regimes. This article provides an overview of the different forms of collaboration in Western and Eastern Europe, as well as beyond the continent.

# Terminology

The term "collaboration" refers to the act of working together, often in a voluntary or cooperative manner, with an enemy or an occupying power. In the context of World War II, collaboration with the Axis powers involved various forms of support, including military, economic, and administrative cooperation. The term "collaborator" refers to an individual or group that engages in such cooperation.

# Collaboration in Western Europe

Western Europe was occupied by Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy, leading to various forms of collaboration in the region.

## Belgium

Belgium was occupied by Germany in May 1940, leading to the establishment of a collaborationist government. The government, led by Hubert Pierlot, cooperated with the German authorities, providing administrative and economic support. The Belgian resistance movement was relatively weak, and many Belgians collaborated with the Germans.

## British Channel Islands

The British Channel Islands were occupied by Germany in June 1940, and the islands' authorities cooperated with the German military. The islands' residents were required to provide food and shelter to German soldiers, and many islanders collaborated with the authorities.

## Denmark

Denmark was occupied by Germany in April 1940, and the Danish government cooperated with the German authorities. The government, led by Thorvald Stauning, provided administrative and economic support, and many Danes collaborated with the Germans.

## France

France was occupied by Germany in June 1940, leading to the establishment of the Vichy regime.

### Vichy France

The Vichy regime, led by Marshal Philippe Pétain, cooperated closely with the German authorities. The regime provided administrative and economic support, and many French citizens collaborated with the Germans.

### Collaborationist movements

Several collaborationist movements emerged in France, including the Milice française and the French Popular Party. These movements provided military and paramilitary support to the German authorities.

### Uniformed collaboration

The French authorities established several uniformed organizations, including the Milice française and the Groupes mobiles de réserve, which cooperated with the German police and military.

### Communist party

The French Communist Party initially cooperated with the German authorities, but later became a key player in the French resistance movement.

### French workers for Germany

The German authorities established the Service du travail obligatoire, which required French workers to work in Germany.

### Vichy collaboration in the Holocaust

The Vichy regime cooperated with the German authorities in the persecution and deportation of French Jews.

### Aftermath

After the war, many French collaborators were tried and executed for their role in the Vichy regime.

## Luxembourg

Luxembourg was occupied by Germany in May 1940, and the Luxembourgish government cooperated with the German authorities. Many Luxembourgish citizens collaborated with the Germans.

## Monaco

Monaco was occupied by Italy in November 1942, and the Monegasque government cooperated with the Italian authorities.

## Netherlands

The Netherlands was occupied by Germany in May 1940, and the Dutch government cooperated with the German authorities. Many Dutch citizens collaborated with the Germans.

## Norway

Norway was occupied by Germany in April 1940, and the Norwegian government cooperated with the German authorities. Many Norwegian citizens collaborated with the Germans.

# Collaboration in Eastern Europe

Eastern Europe was occupied by Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy, leading to various forms of collaboration in the region.

## Albania

Albania was occupied by Italy in April 1939, and the Albanian government cooperated with the Italian authorities.

## Baltic states

The Baltic states, including Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, were occupied by Germany in June 1941.

### Estonia

Estonia was occupied by Germany in June 1941, and the Estonian government cooperated with the German authorities. Many Estonian citizens collaborated with the Germans.

### Lithuania

## Bulgaria

Bulgaria was an ally of Nazi Germany, and the Bulgarian government cooperated closely with the German authorities.

Czecho-Slovakia was occupied by Germany in March 1939.

### Sudetenland

The Sudetenland was annexed by Germany in October 1938, and the Sudeten German Party cooperated with the German authorities.

### Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia (the Czech lands)

The Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia was established in March 1939, and the Czech government cooperated with the German authorities.

### Slovak Republic

The Slovak Republic was established in March 1939, and the Slovak government cooperated with the German authorities.

## Greece

Greece was occupied by Germany, Italy, and Bulgaria in April 1941, and the Greek government cooperated with the occupying powers.

## Hungary

Hungary was an ally of Nazi Germany, and the Hungarian government cooperated closely with the German authorities.

## Poland

Poland was occupied by Germany and the Soviet Union in September 1939, and the Polish government-in-exile cooperated with the Allies.

The Territory of the Military Commander in Serbia was established in April 1941, and the Serbian government cooperated with the German authorities.

## Volunteers from British India

The Indian Legion and the Indian National Army fought for the German and Japanese authorities.

## Non-German units of the Waffen-SS

The Waffen-SS recruited many non-German volunteers, including the Albanian, Bosnian, and Croatian legions.

# Business collaboration

Many businesses collaborated with the Axis powers during World War II.
